summary: in 2009, residents of veracruz, Mexico, became infected with a new strain of swine flu. this disease eventually reached pandemic status, spread across the globe. in 2012, the united states saw two cases of MERS. in 2014, the largest outbreak in history tested the ability of the united states to contain and help eradicate a potentially global pandemic. the CDC flew a top team of health care professionals to contain the disease. they helped direct control of the response, interviewed thousands of people, identified 19 people who had been infected. the successful containment of the disease at its source was vital to keeping Americans safe. Continuing the long-standing public health strategy of helping combat infectious disease at its source and carefully imposing quarantines according to medical and scientific understanding of disease transmission will ultimately place “Americans first”.
